issue_comments.body:
Thanks Dan!
I'm closing this PR.
This pull request referenced the wrong source file. So closing.
thx ;)
ok, thanks!

When testing this fix, I discovered another issue. Don't know if related or not:

Click on the action button (that has the confirm dialog) and cancel the dialog. Then the immediate next click on the button will not fire a click event. Click again and the confirmation dialog pops up again as intended.
Thanks! Can't wait to switch to 1.15 once released! ;)
Sounds very interesting, wish I had a sponsor. ;) Anyway, thanks for the invite!
I need to rebase this, so closing.
merging with PR #79, so closing

Fix for ISIS-1715 menuOrder not honored.
https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ISIS-1715

Thanks Dan, and sorry for the single-branch / multi-feature mix-up ... still learning git. I'll try to do better next time!

BR Andi

Hi Oscar, 

it seems the constructor MemberOrderFacetComparator.<init>(boolean **ensureInSameGroup**) with ensureInSameGroup set to **true** is only used by the LayoutMetadataReaderFromJson class. All other uses seem to have this parameter set to **false**. Maybe the **ensureInSameGroup** parameter is a candidate for deprecation!?

Agreed, I believe LayoutMetadataReaderFromJson just uses ensureInSameGroup as a convenient way to not do the check itself. So maybe we could drop this parameter entirely and remove the branch you mentioned above.

... the actual method that needs to take care of not mixing members is
org.apache.isis.core.metamodel.spec.feature.ObjectAssociation.Util.groupByMemberOrderName(List<ObjectAssociation>)

Glad to help, thanks!
I'll prepare a PR.

Cheers,
Andi

I just realized, that this pattern of XXXComparator.<init>(boolean ensureInSameGroup) is all over the place. On second thought, I'm not sure whether we should break that pattern.

If you don't mind, I'll propose a PR without our discussed 'removal of parameter' idea.

Hi Dan, what do you need me to do?
Cheers
I've merged the slightly refactored version into master. So I'm Closing this PR.

Oscar, is your proposed factory-method-marker meant to be equivalent to what CDI's @Produces annotation does?
If so, (I believe) we need to take account for that in our current domain-object/-service/-view instantiation/injection mechanism as well. But as we plan to move towards CDI anyway, factory-methods will be supported out of the box. So the question is, can you/we wait for CDI to come?

Hi Oscar, I think I now better understand, what you actually had in mind with these factory-method-markers. As you made the distinction between "domain" and "technical",  I would say that I meant "technical", when referring to CDI's @Produces annotation.

I got confused with the term 'factory', which in my mind is hard-linked to object creation. If I understand you correctly, you would like the UI to identify certain methods that should act as domain-object lookups or domain-object providers.

These lookups/providers would be a new kind of support methods (like 'choices', 'default', 'hide' and similar). A kind that supports not just one particular action, but instead supports all declared actions that have a corresponding parameter type and are annotated with @Param(showFactoryMethods=true). 

Very interesting idea! Not so easy to implement I guess ... nested modal dialogs!

Cheers, Andi

Hi Oscar, so these are factories you say. I was thinking of a more general solution for Isis, that could serve even more use-cases (including factories). But I guess I have no concept of how such a solution would actually look like.

Screenshots? Yes sure.

Cheers

Thanks Oscar, your screenshots definitely helped a lot. For me the missing hint was, that you have these nice little icons besides your parameter editors, that provide the above mentioned factory selection.

Maybe if we collaborate on this idea, we might come up with a nice generic solution for Isis. (You use factories, but one could use lookups as well.) Still I feel that the current 'action-support-method' mechanism in Isis is very powerful. Maybe that's the place we look first ...

Cheers

By generic solution I mean abstracting from factories to any supporting method that provides the parameter:

Suppose we have an action with parameters (like in your screenshot). Now for a particular parameter we have this support methods like 'defaultXXX' and 'choicesXXX', which are limited in functionality. We could extend on this by telling Isis, that for a particular parameter in our action there is a certain (or are multiple) provider-method-actions (like your factory-methods) that themselves have arguments. 

Just to give an example of a lookup use-case: 
Imagine you have an entity which you want to pass as an action parameter. Using the 'choices' and 'autocomplete' support methods works great, as long as you conveniently find this entity with a single argument search. But as soon as you would need more than one parameter to narrow down your search, Isis currently shows its limits. Here a new kind of support methods would come in handy.

The issue we are discussing could be labeled 'New Feature: Parameter Providing Support Methods'.

Anyhow for me it's not a 'must have' at the moment. (JEE/CDI support has priority right now.) But it's definitely an extension idea to keep in mind!

Cheers

This can occur if attempt to access non-existent object.  An exception is thrown which takes us to the OnException handler, and then the respondGracefully for the recognised exception again attempts to take us back to the entity page which promptly throws the same exception once more.

So, if this happens we just give up and revert to the original behaviour of showing the error page.

issue_comments.body: I did a cherry pick of this pull request, just to see what happened.  Unlike https://github.com/apache/isis/pull/8, say, where I just did a straightforward merge and everything worked, with a cherry pick (in other words rebase) it seems that github isn't quite smart enough.  So in the future I'll merge PRs using a regular merge.  For this PR, I guess you'll need to close it manually.  I don't think I have the permissions to do that - do you?
Could you recreate the PR referencing ISIS-959 in the commit msg?

Generally looks very good... thanks.  Only main issue is to rename ActionLayout.ClassFaPosition to ActionLayout.CssClassFaPosition.  
If you want to merge it in, I'm happy.

I'm not sure about this pull request.... seems that a new event is created for each phase.

In my original design I create a new event for hide, and for disable, but then reuse the same event for validate/pre-execute/post-execute.  This opens up the possibility that validation phase could (as a performance optimization) "push" results onto the event, to pass downstream to the later *execute phases.  That seems a good thing to me.

With your redesign, that wouldn't be possible.  

What issue does the new design address?

OK, understood.   In which case, your design wins.  
If later on we want to re-introduce the concept of reusing events between phases then we can put the extra machinery back in (Lists, etc).
I'll merge this shortly.

There could be a rare issue with this... the arguments are used to create a cache key, and because you've used the AIFWQRC.class and "invoke" itself, rather than that of the target method that's ultimately called, it's conceivable that caching could occur incorrectly.

eg:
someObject.foo(int, int) -> someObject.bar(int, int)

If both "foo" and "bar" were marked to be cached, then the "foo" cache could be used for "bar".

Sorry for that, I wasn't aware. it's only orthographic. see my comments in bold below from the adoc file. I hope this helps:

-The pages generated by Apache Isis' Wicket viewer are built up of numerous elements, from fine-grained widgets for property/parameter fields, to much larger components that take responsibility for rendering an entire **entity entity**, or a collection of entities. Under the covers these are all implementations of the the Apache Wicket `Component` API. The larger components delegate to the smaller, of course.

I wasn't aware. Again I put my comment in bold below.

issue_comments.body:
Problem is that previous design was not working properly, as it was getting the event from a ThreadLocal that could contain other Event dispatched "in the middle" of another Event's processing (ie, a wrapped property is set in the middle of another Event processing).

So it was reusing an Event that was not corresponding to the same one on previous phases.

As there can be multiple Events simultaneously executing, the only way I envision, if your use case must be supported, is to change from a ThreadLocal single "existingEvent", to a List of them.

HTH,

Oscar 

> El 7/2/2015, a las 12:29, Dan Haywood notifications@github.com escribió:
> 
> I'm not sure about this pull request.... seems that a new event is created for each phase.
> 
> In my original design I create a new event for hide, and for disable, but then reuse the same event for validate/pre-execute/post-execute. This opens up the possibility that validation phase could (as a performance optimization) "push" results onto the event, to pass downstream to the later *execute phases. That seems a good thing to me.
> 
> With your redesign, that wouldn't be possible.
> 
> What issue does the new design address?
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub https://github.com/apache/isis/pull/22#issuecomment-73360587.

> 
> OK, understood. In which case, your design wins.
> 
> If later on we want to re-introduce the concept of reusing events between phases then we can put the extra machinery back in (Lists, etc).
> I'll merge this shortly.

Not sure as it could "mix" in the same sort members from different groups.

But this seems only a guard so somebody must take care previously to not mix members from different groups (despite probably the "global" ordering results could be used by any section).

Nice! 
So we could remove that param without further consequences, as seems that org.apache.isis.core.metamodel.spec.feature.ObjectAssociation.Util.groupByMemberOrderName(List) previously creates a HashMap to group by MemberGroup.

Feel free to patch it and create a PR, and let's Dan finally comment over it ;)

If so, your initial proposal to this PR to delegate to that method would be better than my implementation an this PR could be rejected.
Nice to count with you !!!

Ok Andi. As you consider.
If so let's wait for Dan's opinion once you propose the PR.

Cheers!

Hi Andi. Really interesting question.

An example Domain use case could be the following:

Imagine end users want 2 different ways to instantiate a Book:
- The "fast" one, requiring only to enter a name and an ISBN, the only mandatory properties on that Domain.
- The "complete" one, allowing in addition to the previous ones, to also enter a description, a reference to the Author and more optional data at the very moment you're instantiating the Entity.

Basically we could have something like:

public class BookRepository {
  public Book createBook(final String ISBN, final String name);
  public Book createBookFromAuthor(final String ISBN, final String name, final Author author);
  public Book createBookForArchiving(final String ISBN, final String name, final String description, final Date edition, ...);
  ...
}

With different "create" methods depending on the domain use cases to implement.
Internally, they could reference the "fast" one to delegate base implementation and set additional properties for each derived use case.

From the domain perspective, as far as I would understand it, we would have different Factory Methods from the domain perspective.

AFAIK, in CDI we could use the @Describes annotation with Qualifiers, as there would be different methods that could implement objects of the same Class and we would need to disambiguate.
But on this example they're effectively creating an instance of the same Book class.

Here is the "user" that selects (for "problem solvers") on (or follows for "process followers") each use case one specific implementation.

As current UI generated by Isis is more oriented towards "problem solvers", giving users the different actions, menus, etc. available, if we annotate in some way all methods that from the Domain perspective can be used to instantiate the Book class from the user's perspective, we can, for example, show all them to the user when a reference must be entered of a given class, allowing to select a previously existing instance or a new one.
Exemplyfing it, imagine we show on the modal dialog invoking an action, for each param that can reference a Book, a drop-down menu with all the previous 3 options, giving the user the opportunity to select an existing Book or create a new one right in that very moment.

Perhaps that behaviour (showing the sub-menu with known factory methods) can be the default one for all params in action dialogs, and perhaps it needs to be avoided by something like @Param(showFactoryMethods=false) - being the default value "true" -.


In this case, would you consider these factory methods a "domain" issue rather than a "technical" one - like CDI, where the annotation would inject new instances automatically -?

Despite that, I never thought of using the @Produces annotation for this and think can be a good solution for the most common use case. 
The equivalent could be then a menu for all Qualifiers for the @Produces associated with the Entity class.
 
Sorry for the extension ...

Hi Andi,

They’re effectively factory methods, creating new instances. Never return existing ones (not lookups).

We have them currently implemented in our custom viewer and allow the user to create a new instance when asking for a reference on an action param (avoiding context switching through a modal over modal dialog) but also to show a “New” button on each entity showing the different Actions annotated with @FactoryMethod that allow to create a new instance (of the given class or any descendant).

Clearer now? I can attach a screenshot.

Hi Andi. The first image shows an action with a param where you can select an existing "Threat Source" or create one of 2 specialized ones ("Adversarial Threat Agent", "Non Adversarial Threat Agent"). When selected on of them, a modal-over-modal dialog is showed allowing to create the new object. If created, the viewer automatically select it as the current value for the param. Did it help? Any doubts? Cheers, Oscar

Sure Andi!
For me the "hard thing" is the viewer, and you're proficient on that.

What do you mean with generic lookups? 
Can you explain further or give an example?

Thanks!

Aha! So something like custom “domain” finders.

Interesting !!! And find it useful also ... 

Should we ask for more opinions on this on the dev list? 

Please, lead this if you consider
